title: John Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on John chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: John Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of John Chapter 7.

questions.question: Why did Jesus not walk openly in Jewry according to John 7?
options: Because the Jews sought to kill him
Because he was afraid of the Pharisees
Because he was not welcome there
Because he was sick
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Jews sought to kill him
questions.explanation: John 7:1 states that Jesus would not walk in Jewry because the Jews sought to kill him.

questions.question: What feast was at hand in John 7?
options: The feast of tabernacles
The feast of unleavened bread
The feast of Pentecost
The feast of Passover
questions.correctAnswer: The feast of tabernacles
questions.explanation: John 7:2 mentions that the Jews' feast of tabernacles was at hand.

questions.question: Who told Jesus to go into Judaea so his disciples might see his works?
options: His brethren
The Pharisees
The chief priests
The disciples
questions.correctAnswer: His brethren
questions.explanation: John 7:3 states that Jesus' brethren said unto him to go into Judaea.

questions.question: What reason did Jesus give for not yet going to the feast openly?
options: His time was not yet come
He was feeling unwell
The feast was not important to him
He wanted to avoid the crowds
questions.correctAnswer: His time was not yet come
questions.explanation: John 7:6-8 records Jesus saying his time was not yet come to go openly to the feast.

questions.question: How did Jesus go to the feast after his brethren had gone up?
options: Not openly, but as it were in secret
With a large crowd
On a donkey
In a chariot
questions.correctAnswer: Not openly, but as it were in secret
questions.explanation: John 7:10 states Jesus went to the feast not openly, but in secret.

questions.question: What did some people say about Jesus at the feast?
options: He is a good man
He is a carpenter
He is a prophet from Egypt
He is a Roman
questions.correctAnswer: He is a good man
questions.explanation: John 7:12 says some said Jesus is a good man, others said he deceiveth the people.

questions.question: Where did Jesus go to teach about the midst of the feast?
options: Into the temple
To the mountaintop
To the marketplace
To the synagogue
questions.correctAnswer: Into the temple
questions.explanation: John 7:14 states Jesus went up into the temple and taught.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Jews to Jesus' knowledge according to John 7?
options: They marveled because he had never learned
They ignored him
They praised the Pharisees
They asked him to leave
questions.correctAnswer: They marveled because he had never learned
questions.explanation: John 7:15 records the Jews marveling how Jesus knew letters without learning.

questions.question: According to Jesus, whose doctrine did he teach?
options: His doctrine is not his, but of him that sent him
His own doctrine
The doctrine of the Pharisees
The doctrine of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: His doctrine is not his, but of him that sent him
questions.explanation: John 7:16 quotes Jesus saying his doctrine is from the one who sent him.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said that the world hates him because he testifies that the works of the world are evil.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 7:7 states the world hates Jesus because he testifies the works thereof are evil.

questions.question: True or False: The Pharisees and chief priests sent officers to take Jesus at the feast.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 7:32 states the Pharisees and chief priests sent officers to take Jesus.

questions.question: True or False: Nicodemus was one of those who came to Jesus by day according to John 7.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 7:50 identifies Nicodemus as the one who came to Jesus by night.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'In the last day, that great day of the feast, Jesus stood and cried, saying, If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and ______.'
options: drink
listen
pray
believe
questions.correctAnswer: drink
questions.explanation: John 7:37 records Jesus saying 'If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink.'

questions.question: According to John 7, what flows out of the belly of those who believe in Jesus?
options: Rivers of living water
Streams of milk
Waves of fire
Springs of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Rivers of living water
questions.explanation: John 7:38 states that out of the belly of believers shall flow rivers of living water.

questions.question: What did the officers say when asked why they had not brought Jesus?
options: Never man spake like this man
He escaped
He was not there
He was hiding
questions.correctAnswer: Never man spake like this man
questions.explanation: John 7:46 records the officers saying 'Never man spake like this man.'

medium.title: John Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from John Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feeling rejected for their faith. Based on John 7, what biblical truth would you share about enduring such trials?
options: The world hates those who testify against its evil works.
God will remove all enemies immediately.
Believers should avoid public witness to stay safe.
Faith guarantees a comfortable life.
questions.correctAnswer: The world hates those who testify against its evil works.
questions.explanation: John 7:7 teaches that the world hates Jesus because He testifies against its evil works, implying believers may face hatred for standing firm in faith. This encourages perseverance through trials (John 7:1, 7:30).

questions.question: How does John 7 instruct us to handle judgment and discernment in daily life?
options: Judge not according to appearance, but with righteous judgment.
Judge harshly to correct others quickly.
Ignore all judgments to avoid conflict.
Judge only those outside the church.
questions.correctAnswer: Judge not according to appearance, but with righteous judgment.
questions.explanation: John 7:24 advises us to avoid superficial judgment and to seek righteous judgment, promoting fairness and integrity in how we assess others.

questions.question: A believer is confused about Jesus' teachings because He had no formal schooling. Based on John 7, how can we understand the source of His wisdom?
options: His doctrine is from God who sent Him.
He learned from the religious leaders secretly.
He taught only what He invented himself.
He copied teachings from Moses.
questions.correctAnswer: His doctrine is from God who sent Him.
questions.explanation: John 7:15-17 shows that Jesus’ teaching amazed the Jews because He had not studied formally, but His doctrine is from God, and those who do God's will will recognize its divine source.

questions.question: What does John 7 teach about the proper response to God's will and teachings?
options: If anyone does God's will, they will know the doctrine is from God.
Faith is not necessary to recognize God's truth.
Only scholars can understand God's teachings.
God's will is a mystery that cannot be understood.
questions.correctAnswer: If anyone does God's will, they will know the doctrine is from God.
questions.explanation: John 7:17 explains that obedience to God’s will enables a person to discern the truth of Jesus’ teachings, highlighting the importance of faith and action.

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged because others doubt their faith. According to John 7, what example can encourage them regarding public witness?
options: Jesus initially went to the feast in secret but later taught boldly in the temple.
Followers should hide their faith to avoid criticism.
Faith should only be practiced privately.
Public proclamation is unnecessary for discipleship.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus initially went to the feast in secret but later taught boldly in the temple.
questions.explanation: John 7:10 and 7:14 show Jesus’ careful timing—He first came in secret but then taught openly, encouraging believers to be bold in sharing their faith when the time is right.

questions.question: How does John 7 encourage believers to handle division or disagreement within the church community?
options: Recognize that differences of opinion may arise about Christ but remain open to truth.
Reject anyone who disagrees as a heretic.
Avoid all discussion to maintain peace.
Only accept those who come from your own region.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that differences of opinion may arise about Christ but remain open to truth.
questions.explanation: John 7:41-43 describes division among the people about Jesus’ identity, teaching that disagreement is natural, but believers should seek understanding and unity in truth.

questions.question: A Christian is tempted to judge others superficially. Based on John 7, what principle should guide their judgment?
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 7:24 instructs believers to not judge by outward appearance but to judge righteously, reminding us to avoid superficial or unfair judgments.

questions.question: Does John 7 indicate that Jesus sought His own glory in His teachings?
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 7:18 states that Jesus did not seek His own glory but the glory of the One who sent Him, emphasizing humility and obedience in His ministry.

questions.question: Jesus spoke about rivers of living water flowing from those who believe in Him. What does this symbolize according to John 7?
options: The Holy Spirit given to believers after Jesus is glorified.
A literal river that believers will find.
Physical water from wells in the temple.
Material blessings for the faithful.
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit given to believers after Jesus is glorified.
questions.explanation: John 7:38-39 explains that the 'living water' represents the Holy Spirit that believers would receive after Jesus’ glorification, highlighting spiritual renewal and empowerment.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about being misunderstood or accused by others. How does Jesus' experience in John 7 provide guidance?
options: Jesus was accused of having a demon and deceiving people, yet He continued to fulfill His mission.
Jesus avoided all public interaction to stay safe.
Jesus only taught those who fully accepted Him.
Jesus responded with retaliation against His accusers.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus was accused of having a demon and deceiving people, yet He continued to fulfill His mission.
questions.explanation: John 7:20 and 7:44 show that Jesus faced false accusations but remained steadfast in His work, teaching believers to persevere despite misunderstanding.

questions.question: What does John 7 teach about the relationship between obeying God's law and showing compassion in practical ways?
options: It is right to heal and do good on the Sabbath, showing mercy over strict ritual.
No deeds should be done on the Sabbath.
Only ritual observance matters, not compassion.
Mercy is optional and not part of the law.
questions.correctAnswer: It is right to heal and do good on the Sabbath, showing mercy over strict ritual.
questions.explanation: John 7:21-23 highlights Jesus’ healing on the Sabbath and challenges the hypocrisy of the religious leaders, teaching practical mercy and obedience to God's intent.

questions.question: A believer feels uncertain about Jesus’ origins and identity. What does John 7 reveal about Jesus’ claim regarding His origin?
options: Jesus said He knows God because He is sent from Him.
Jesus refused to say where He came from.
Jesus claimed to be from Galilee only.
Jesus said no one can know where He is from.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus said He knows God because He is sent from Him.
questions.explanation: John 7:28-29 shows Jesus declaring His divine origin and mission, affirming His unique relationship with God the Father to dispel doubts.

questions.question: How does John 7 instruct believers about seeking Jesus after His departure?
options: They will seek Him but not find Him, because He will go to the Father.
They will easily find Him anywhere.
Jesus will remain physically present among them forever.
They will find Him only in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: They will seek Him but not find Him, because He will go to the Father.
questions.explanation: John 7:33-34 records Jesus saying He will go to the One who sent Him and people will seek Him but not find Him, teaching about His ascension and spiritual invisibility.

questions.question: A believer is invited to the Feast of Tabernacles but is unsure when to go. What lesson can be learned from Jesus’ timing in John 7?
options: Jesus delayed going because His time had not yet come, showing obedience to God's timing.
Jesus went immediately to please others.
Jesus ignored the feast entirely.
Jesus refused to attend any Jewish festivals.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus delayed going because His time had not yet come, showing obedience to God's timing.
questions.explanation: John 7:6-10 shows Jesus explaining that His timing is controlled by God’s plan, teaching believers to trust God's timing in their lives.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus said, 'If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink. He that believeth on me, as the scripture hath said, out of his belly shall flow rivers of ________ water.'
options: living
cold
stagnant
clear
questions.correctAnswer: living
questions.explanation: John 7:37-38 states that believers receive 'rivers of living water,' symbolizing the life-giving Holy Spirit that flows from faith in Jesus.

hard.title: John Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from John Chapter 7.

questions.question: What reason does Jesus give for not going up to the feast of tabernacles at the same time as his brethren?
options: His time was not yet come
He was afraid of the Pharisees
He wanted to avoid the crowds
He was unwell
questions.correctAnswer: His time was not yet come
questions.explanation: Jesus explicitly states that his time was not yet come, indicating divine timing governs his actions (John 7:6-8).

questions.question: How do the Jews react to Jesus' teaching at the feast according to John 7:12?
options: Some said He is a good man, others said He deceiveth the people
They all accepted Him as the Christ
They ignored Him completely
They immediately arrested Him
questions.correctAnswer: Some said He is a good man, others said He deceiveth the people
questions.explanation: Verse John 7:12 shows division among the people, reflecting skepticism and varied opinions about Jesus.

questions.question: What teaching method does Jesus use when he speaks in the temple about His doctrine?
options: He declares that his doctrine is from God who sent Him
He quotes extensively from the Torah without explanation
He uses parables exclusively
He refuses to answer any questions
questions.correctAnswer: He declares that his doctrine is from God who sent Him
questions.explanation: Jesus clarifies that His teaching is not His own but from God, emphasizing divine authority (John 7:16).

questions.question: In John 7:19, Jesus challenges the Jews by comparing their behavior to that of Moses' law. What hypocrisy does He highlight?
options: They seek to kill Him despite not fully keeping the law themselves
They honor Moses but reject the prophets
They observe the Sabbath but not the Passover
They tithe but neglect justice
questions.correctAnswer: They seek to kill Him despite not fully keeping the law themselves
questions.explanation: Jesus points out their failure to keep the law while plotting to kill Him, exposing their inconsistency (John 7:19).

questions.question: According to John 7:22-23, why do the Jews not criticize circumcision on the Sabbath but are angry at Jesus for healing on the Sabbath?
options: Because circumcision was given by Moses and is necessary, but healing was seen as work
Because healing was forbidden on all holy days
Because Jesus did not perform a miracle
Because circumcision was not considered a law
questions.correctAnswer: Because circumcision was given by Moses and is necessary, but healing was seen as work
questions.explanation: Jesus contrasts their acceptance of circumcision on the Sabbath, which is lawful, with their anger at His healing, challenging their judgment (John 7:22-23).

questions.question: What principle does Jesus teach in John 7:24 regarding judgment?
options: Judge righteous judgment, not according to appearance
Judge quickly and with zeal
Judge only when commanded by leaders
Judge based on popular opinion
questions.correctAnswer: Judge righteous judgment, not according to appearance
questions.explanation: Jesus instructs to judge with righteousness rather than superficial appearances, emphasizing true justice (John 7:24).

questions.question: How do some people in Jerusalem respond to Jesus speaking boldly during the feast according to John 7:25-26?
options: They wonder if He is the Christ and note His boldness
They immediately reject Him as a heretic
They arrest Him on the spot
They ask Him to leave the city
questions.correctAnswer: They wonder if He is the Christ and note His boldness
questions.explanation: Verses 25-26 reveal the crowd's mixed reactions, including recognition of His boldness and questioning His identity as the Christ.

questions.question: What does Jesus claim about His origin and His relationship with the sender in John 7:28-29?
options: He is from God and was sent by Him, whom He knows
He is from Nazareth and speaks on His own authority
He is from the synagogue and was chosen by the Pharisees
He is from Galilee but unknown to God
questions.correctAnswer: He is from God and was sent by Him, whom He knows
questions.explanation: Jesus declares He is sent by God and knows Him, asserting divine origin and authority (John 7:28-29).

questions.question: Why were the officers unable to seize Jesus at the feast according to John 7:30?
options: Because His hour was not yet come
Because He escaped through the crowds
Because the people protected Him
Because the Pharisees forbade it
questions.correctAnswer: Because His hour was not yet come
questions.explanation: The text states no one laid hands on Him because the appointed time for His arrest had not yet arrived (John 7:30).

questions.question: What does Jesus say on the last day of the feast, inviting those who thirst to come to Him (John 7:37-38)?
options: If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink
Come and receive manna from heaven
Follow me and you shall never hunger
Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth
questions.correctAnswer: If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink
questions.explanation: Jesus offers living water as spiritual sustenance, inviting all who are spiritually thirsty to come to Him (John 7:37-38).

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'living water' Jesus speaks of in John 7:39?
options: It refers to the Holy Spirit believers would receive
It refers to actual water from the temple
It refers to the Jordan River
It refers to a future rain in Galilee
questions.correctAnswer: It refers to the Holy Spirit believers would receive
questions.explanation: The passage clarifies that 'living water' symbolizes the Spirit given after Jesus is glorified (John 7:39).

questions.question: What division arises among the people regarding Jesus after His teaching at the feast (John 7:40-43)?
options: Some say He is the Prophet, others say He is the Christ, others doubt because Christ should come from Bethlehem
All agree He is the Messiah
They unanimously reject Him as a false teacher
They decide to follow the Pharisees instead
questions.correctAnswer: Some say He is the Prophet, others say He is the Christ, others doubt because Christ should come from Bethlehem
questions.explanation: The crowd is divided over Jesus’ identity, showing differing expectations of the Messiah (John 7:40-43).

questions.question: How do the officers describe Jesus' speech when questioned by the chief priests and Pharisees (John 7:46)?
options: Never man spake like this man
He speaks nonsense
He uses blasphemy
His words are confusing
questions.correctAnswer: Never man spake like this man
questions.explanation: The officers are impressed by Jesus’ unique and authoritative speech (John 7:46).

questions.question: What argument does Nicodemus use to defend Jesus in the council (John 7:50-51)?
options: Our law does not judge a man before hearing him and knowing what he does
Jesus performed miracles publicly
The people desire peace
He is a prophet from Galilee
questions.correctAnswer: Our law does not judge a man before hearing him and knowing what he does
questions.explanation: Nicodemus appeals to the legal principle of fair hearing before judgment (John 7:50-51).

questions.question: True or False: The Pharisees believed in Jesus and supported Nicodemus' defense of Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The Pharisees rejected Jesus and questioned Nicodemus, showing no belief in Jesus (John 7:47-48).

theological.title: John Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from John Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Why did Jesus initially avoid walking in Jewry according to John 7?
options: Because the Jews sought to kill him
Because it was not the appointed time
Because he was going to Galilee
Because he was teaching in secret
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Jews sought to kill him
questions.explanation: John 7:1 states that Jesus walked in Galilee because he would not walk in Jewry since the Jews sought to kill him. This reflects the theme of opposition to Jesus seen in Psalms 2:2 and Isaiah 53:3, where the Messiah is rejected and persecuted.

questions.question: What feast was at hand during the events of John 7?
options: The Feast of Tabernacles
Passover
Pentecost
The Feast of Unleavened Bread
questions.correctAnswer: The Feast of Tabernacles
questions.explanation: John 7:2 identifies the feast as the Jews' Feast of Tabernacles, which is a significant Old Testament festival described in Leviticus 23:34-44 and symbolizes God's provision and dwelling with His people, linking to Jesus' later teaching of living water.

questions.question: What was the attitude of Jesus' brothers toward him before his public ministry?
options: They did not believe in him
They fully supported him
They were unaware of his works
They sought to follow him secretly
questions.correctAnswer: They did not believe in him
questions.explanation: John 7:5 states that even Jesus' own brothers did not believe in him, showing the initial unbelief even among his close family, consistent with themes of rejection in Isaiah 53:3 and Psalm 69:8.

questions.question: According to Jesus in John 7:6-8, what is the reason he did not immediately go to the feast with his brothers?
options: His time had not yet come
He was afraid of the Jews
He was unwell
He was waiting for a sign
questions.correctAnswer: His time had not yet come
questions.explanation: Jesus explained in John 7:6-8 that his 'time' had not yet come, indicating divine timing and sovereignty in his ministry, reflecting the Messianic fulfillment themes in Psalm 40:6-8 and Daniel 9:24.

questions.question: How did the people react when Jesus taught in the temple during the feast?
options: Some said he was a good man, others said he deceived the people
All accepted him as the Messiah
They ignored him completely
They immediately arrested him
questions.correctAnswer: Some said he was a good man, others said he deceived the people
questions.explanation: John 7:12 records mixed reactions, highlighting the division and skepticism toward Jesus, which aligns with the prophetic conflict in Isaiah 53:3 and Jeremiah 20:7 where the servant is both praised and rejected.

questions.question: What did Jesus claim about the origin of his teaching in John 7:16?
options: His doctrine is from the one who sent him
His doctrine is his own invention
He learned it from the Pharisees
He received it through human tradition
questions.correctAnswer: His doctrine is from the one who sent him
questions.explanation: In John 7:16, Jesus asserts that his teaching is not his own but from God who sent him, emphasizing his divine authority, consistent with Deuteronomy 18:18 and Isaiah 61:1-3 regarding the prophet sent by God.

questions.question: What principle about judgment does Jesus teach in John 7:24?
options: Judge not according to appearance, but judge righteous judgment
Judge harshly to maintain order
Judge only when commanded by authorities
Judge according to popular opinion
questions.correctAnswer: Judge not according to appearance, but judge righteous judgment
questions.explanation: Jesus instructs in John 7:24 to judge righteously rather than superficially, which aligns with Old Testament justice commands in Leviticus 19:15 and Proverbs 31:9, emphasizing God's standard for justice.

questions.question: What miracle did Jesus refer to in John 7:21 to demonstrate his authority?
options: Healing a man completely on the Sabbath
Feeding the five thousand
Raising Lazarus from the dead
Walking on water
questions.correctAnswer: Healing a man completely on the Sabbath
questions.explanation: John 7:21-23 references Jesus healing a man fully on the Sabbath, challenging Pharisaic interpretations of the law, echoing themes of mercy over sacrifice in Hosea 6:6 and Isaiah 58:6-7.

questions.question: What did Jesus say about those who speak of themselves in John 7:18?
options: They seek their own glory
They are always truthful
They speak with divine authority
They are misunderstood prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They seek their own glory
questions.explanation: John 7:18 teaches that those who speak on their own seek personal glory, contrasting with Jesus who seeks the glory of the one who sent him, paralleling John 5:41 and Isaiah 42:1 about God's servant.

questions.question: According to John 7:37-38, what does Jesus offer to those who thirst?
options: Living water
Earthly riches
Political power
Physical healing
questions.correctAnswer: Living water
questions.explanation: Jesus offers 'living water' to those who thirst, symbolizing the Holy Spirit and eternal life, as explained in John 7:39 and supported by Isaiah 55:1 and Ezekiel 47:1-12 where water represents life and renewal.

questions.question: What was the people's reaction to Jesus' claim about living water, according to John 7:40-42?
options: They were divided, some calling him the Prophet or Christ, others questioning his origin
They unanimously accepted him as the Messiah
They ignored his claims
They arrested him immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They were divided, some calling him the Prophet or Christ, others questioning his origin
questions.explanation: John 7:40-42 describes a division among the people about Jesus' identity, with some seeing him as the Prophet or Christ, others doubting because of his Galilean origin, reflecting the Messianic expectations in Deuteronomy 18:15 and Micah 5:2.

questions.question: Why did the officers sent to arrest Jesus fail to do so according to John 7:30 and John 7:44?
options: Because his hour had not yet come
Because Jesus escaped through the crowd
Because the rulers stopped them
Because Jesus was not present
questions.correctAnswer: Because his hour had not yet come
questions.explanation: John 7:30 and 7:44 indicate that Jesus was not arrested because the appointed time for his passion had not yet arrived, emphasizing divine sovereignty over the timing of salvation events, as seen in Mark 14:41 and Luke 22:53.

questions.question: What was Nicodemus' argument regarding Jesus in John 7:50-51?
options: That the law requires hearing a man before judging him
That Jesus was a false teacher
That Jesus should be arrested immediately
That Galilee was the source of all prophets
questions.correctAnswer: That the law requires hearing a man before judging him
questions.explanation: Nicodemus appealed to the law's requirement of fair hearing before judgment (John 7:50-51), reflecting principles of justice in Deuteronomy 1:16-17 and Proverbs 18:13, underscoring the importance of righteous judgment.

questions.question: How did the Pharisees respond to Nicodemus' defense of Jesus in John 7:52?
options: They rejected him because he was from Galilee
They agreed to consider Jesus' case
They praised his courage
They remained silent
questions.correctAnswer: They rejected him because he was from Galilee
questions.explanation: John 7:52 shows the Pharisees dismissing Nicodemus' defense by asserting no prophet arises from Galilee, ignoring Scriptural prophecy such as Jonah 1:1 and Nahum 1:1 about God’s work beyond Jerusalem, revealing their rejection of God's sovereignty.

questions.question: What does John 7:29 reveal about Jesus' relationship to God the Father?
options: Jesus knows God because He is from Him and sent by Him
Jesus acts independently of God
Jesus is uncertain of His origin
Jesus seeks His own glory
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus knows God because He is from Him and sent by Him
questions.explanation: John 7:29 affirms Jesus' intimate knowledge of God, declaring His divine origin and mission, consistent with John 1:1-3 and Hebrews 1:3, emphasizing the unity of the Son with the Father in salvation history.
